lexicon_requests.reason: Opening beatitude formula - plural construct form, exact force and usage pattern across Psalms
Climactic third wicked category - semantic range distinguishing from רְשָׁעִים/חַטָּאִים
Central meditation verb - ambiguity between vocalized/embodied vs. silent, compare Ps 2:1 usage
Affective/covenantal dimension - delight vs. duty, legal vs. emotional register
Passive participle planting - agency implications, compare natural vs. transplanted terminology
Water channels (plural construct) - natural streams vs. irrigation, divine provision imagery
Withering/fading verb (לֹא־יִבּוֹל) - agricultural technical term, contrast with flourishing
Chaff imagery - agricultural/threshing context, cultural background, judgment associations
Dispersal verb (wind-driven) - semantic range, violence vs. natural scattering
Judicial standing (יָקֻמוּ) - forensic vs. resurrection semantics in judgment context
Assembly term (עֲדַת צַדִּיקִים) - cultic, covenantal, eschatological usage patterns
Divine knowing (יוֹדֵעַ) - epistemological vs. covenantal vs. constitutive/ontological semantics

concordance_requests.purpose: Track beatitude formula opening pattern across Psalter
Walking in counsel idiom - moral/spatial associations
Standing in way/path - judicial and spatial uses
Sitting in seat - settlement and social position terminology
Day and night meditation formula - compare Josh 1:8 and continuous practice idiom
Planted tree imagery - transplanting vs. natural growth metaphors
Fruit in season - divine timing and appropriateness theme
Unable to stand in judgment - forensic/eschatological formula
In/at judgment - cultic, legal, eschatological contexts in Psalter
Assembly of righteous - cultic/eschatological community terminology
YHWH knows the way - divine epistemology and covenantal recognition formula
Way of wicked - two ways theology contrast patterns
Perishing - self-destruction vs. divine judgment semantics in Psalter

figurative_requests.reason: Walking/standing/sitting progression - spatial metaphors for moral entanglement stages | Vehicle: walk | Related terms: walking, walked, walks, go, going, goes, went

Torah meditation as continuous temporal practice - day and night merismus | Vehicle: meditate | Related terms: meditates, meditating, meditation, mutter, mutters, muttering, murmur, murmurs, murmuring
Tree planted by water streams - central flourishing metaphor with passive agency | Vehicle: tree | Related terms: trees, plant, plants, planted, planting
Water channels/streams - sustaining force imagery, natural vs. engineered | Vehicle: streams | Related terms: stream, channel, channels, watercourse, watercourses, river, rivers
Fruit-bearing in season - temporal appropriateness and divine timing | Vehicle: fruit | Related terms: fruits, bear fruit, bearing fruit, fruitful, fruitfulness
Foliage not withering - permanence and vitality imagery | Vehicle: wither | Related terms: withers, withering, withered, fade, fades, fading, faded, wilt, wilts, wilting
Chaff imagery - weightlessness and agricultural waste as wickedness metaphor | Vehicle: chaff | Related terms: husks, straw, stubble
Wind-driven dispersal - violent scattering and insubstantiality | Vehicle: driven | Related terms: drive, drives, driving, blow, blows, blowing, blown, scatter, scatters, scattering, scattered
Standing in judgment - forensic/judicial metaphor for vindication or condemnation | Vehicle: stand | Related terms: standing, stands, stood, arise, arises, arising, arose, rise, rises, rising, rose
Divine knowing - covenantal recognition vs. epistemological awareness | Vehicle: know | Related terms: knows, knowing, knew, known, recognize, recognizes, recognizing, recognized

Way/path perishing - ontological dissolution and ceasing to exist | Vehicle: perish | Related terms: perishes, perishing, perished, destroy, destroys, destroying, destroyed, vanish, vanishes, vanishing, vanished

commentary_requests.reason: Opening beatitude formula - how do commentators interpret אַשְׁרֵי structure and threefold negative progression of walk/stand/sit with three wicked categories?
Torah meditation practice - traditional understanding of חֵפֶץ (delight vs. duty) and יֶהְגֶּה (vocalized vs. silent practice), day/night merismus significance
Tree metaphor elaboration - classical interpretation of שָׁתוּל (passive planting, divine agency), water channels imagery, fruitfulness in season, comprehensive success promise
Chaff imagery brevity - how commentators explain dramatic structural asymmetry and insubstantiality metaphor, contrast with elaborate tree description
Judgment and assembly language - traditional eschatology of יָקֻמוּ (standing/arising), forensic vs. eschatological בַּמִּשְׁפָּט, nature of עֲדַת צַדִּיקִים
Two ways theology climax - how commentators frame יוֹדֵעַ (YHWH's knowing as covenantal/constitutive), תֹּאבֵד (self-destruction vs. divine judgment), דֶּרֶךְ inclusio significance

macro_questions: What is the precise semantic range of הָלַךְ/עָמָד/יָשָׁב (walk/stand/sit) in v. 1—are these technical terms for levels of commitment, spatial metaphors for social proximity, or simply synonymous variations? How does this triadic progression function in other wisdom texts?

What does יֶהְגֶּה (meditate/murmur/mutter) mean in v. 2? Does it suggest vocalized, embodied practice (murmuring, recitation) or internal contemplation? How is this term used elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible (Josh 1:8; Ps 2:1; Isa 31:4)?

Is the passive participle שָׁתוּל (planted) in v. 3 significant theologically? Does it suggest the righteous person is passively transformed by God rather than self-made? Who is the implied agent of planting?

What is the symbolic and agricultural background of chaff (מֹץ) imagery in v. 4? How does this relate to threshing floor scenes as judgment contexts elsewhere in Scripture (Ruth 3; 2 Sam 24; prophetic literature)?
What does יָקֻמוּ (stand/arise) mean in v. 5—is this judicial language (standing in court), resurrection/eschatological imagery, or both? What is 'the judgment' (בַּמִּשְׁפָּט) referenced here?

What is the 'assembly of the righteous' (עֲדַת צַדִּיקִים) in v. 5? Is this a liturgical/cultic gathering, eschatological community, or metaphor for the blessed state? How does עֵדָה function in Psalms?

What does יוֹדֵעַ (knows) connote in v. 6? Is this epistemological (God is aware), relational/covenantal (God acknowledges in relationship, cf. Amos 3:2; Gen 18:19), or ontological (God's knowledge constitutes reality)? What is the 'knowing' God does?

How do the three wicked categories in v. 1—רְשָׁעִים (wicked), חַטָּאִים (sinners), לֵצִים (scoffers/insolent)—relate to each other? Are they synonymous, progressive, or distinct types? What is the specific nuance of לֵצִים?
What is the function of כִּי in vv. 2 and 6? Is it causal (because), emphatic (indeed/surely), adversative (but), or asseverative? How does this affect the logical flow?

How does Psalm 1 function redactionally as introduction to the Psalter? What connections exist with Psalm 2 (some manuscripts combine them; both mention meditation/muttering-הָגָה; both end with blessing)? How does it reframe the cultic psalms as Torah meditation?
micro_questions: What is the precise semantic range and function of יֶהְגֶּה (meditate/mutter) in v. 2—does it indicate vocalized recitation, embodied murmuring, or silent contemplation, and how does this compare with its usage in Josh 1:8 and Ps 2:1?

Why does the triadic progression in v. 1 use specifically הָלַךְ/עָמָד/יָשָׁב (walk/stand/sit)—are these technical terms for levels of social commitment, spatial metaphors for proximity to wickedness, or synonymous variations for poetic effect?

What is the theological significance of שָׁתוּל (planted) being a passive participle in v. 3—does this suggest divine agency in positioning the righteous, and if so, how does this affect interpretation of human moral responsibility?

How do the three wicked categories in v. 1 (רְשָׁעִים/חַטָּאִים/לֵצִים - wicked/sinners/scoffers) relate to each other—are they progressive stages of moral deterioration, distinct types of wickedness, or synonymous terms, and what is the specific nuance of לֵצִים?

What does יוֹדֵעַ (knows) connote in v. 6—is this epistemological awareness, covenantal/relational recognition (as in Amos 3:2; Gen 18:19), or constitutive ontological knowing that brings reality into being?

What is בַּמִּשְׁפָּט (the judgment) in v. 5—earthly legal proceeding, divine judgment scene, eschatological event, or all three, and does יָקֻמוּ (stand/arise) carry resurrection imagery or purely judicial connotations?

What is the agricultural and cultural background of מֹץ (chaff) imagery in v. 4, and how does this relate to threshing floor scenes as judgment contexts elsewhere in Scripture (Ruth 3; 2 Sam 24; prophetic literature)?

Why is the description of the wicked so dramatically brief compared to the righteous (structural asymmetry)—is this aesthetic choice, rhetorical strategy, or theological statement about substance vs insubstantiality?

What is עֲדַת צַדִּיקִים (assembly of the righteous) in v. 5—liturgical/cultic gathering, eschatological community, covenant assembly, or metaphor for blessed state, and how does עֵדָה function elsewhere in Psalms?

How does the passive תֹּאבֵד (perishes) in v. 6 differ from active divine judgment language—does the wicked way self-destruct through lack of divine knowing, or is this euphemistic language for divine destruction?
What is the function of כִּי in vv. 2 and 6—causal (because), emphatic (indeed), adversative (but), or explanatory, and how does this affect the logical and theological flow of the psalm?

Does פַּלְגֵי־מָיִם (streams/channels of water) in v. 3 suggest natural watercourses or engineered irrigation channels, and does this distinction matter for understanding divine vs human agency in flourishing?

How does Psalm 1's use of הָגָה (meditate) in v. 2 for Torah study contrast with Psalm 2:1's use of the same verb for nations 'plotting'—is this intentional wordplay establishing contrasting meditations?
